telescopes.name: FAST Radio Telescope
telescopes.description: The Five-hundred-meter Aperture Spherical radio Telescope (FAST; 五百米口径球面射电望远镜), nicknamed Tianyan (天眼), is a radio telescope located Guizhou.

telescopes.name: PAST Radio Telescope
telescopes.description: The Primeval Structure Telescope (PaST), also called 21 Centimetre Array (21CMA), is a Chinese radio telescope array designed to detect the earliest luminous objects in the universe, including the first stars, supernova explosions, and black holes.

telescopes.name: LAMOST (Guo Shoujing)
telescopes.description: The Large Sky Area Multi-Object Fibre Spectroscopic Telescope (LAMOST), also known as the Guo Shoujing Telescope ( 郭守敬望远镜) after the 13th-century Chinese astronomer, is a meridian reflecting Schmidt telescope, located in Xinglong Station, Hebei.

telescopes.name: HXMT (Insight)
telescopes.description: Hard X-ray Modulation Telescope (HXMT) also known as Insight (慧眼) is an X-ray space observatory, launched on June 15, 2017 to observe black holes, neutron stars, active galactic nuclei and other phenomena based on their X-ray and gamma-ray emissions.

comments.text: Its construction was completed in September 2016 and it officially began operating in January 2020.
Measuring 500 meters in diameter, FAST is the largest radio telescope in the world.
FAST is expected to map the neutral hydrogen gas in the Milky Way Galaxy at a very high resolution and to increase the number of known pulsars from almost 2,000 to about 6,000.
FAST may be able to detect radio emissions from extrasolar planets that are similar to Jupiter.
It also should be able to search for signals from extraterrestrial intelligence around many more stars than in previous surveys.
Located  on the high plateau of Ulastai in the west of Xinjiang province.
Built in 2004.
Captures radio image of the sky in the range of 1420 megahertz.
The Hydrogen Line is another name for the 21cm line.
It's remote location avoids interferance from other radio and television signals
LAMOST is part of Xingliong Station
It is planned to conduct a 5-year spectroscopic survey of 10 million Milky Way stars, as well as millions of galaxies.
The project's budget is RMB 235 million yuan.
Using active optics technique to control its reflecting corrector makes it a unique astronomical instrument in combining large aperture with wide field of view.
The telescope's location, only 115 km (71 mi) NW of Beijing, is far from ideal.
It is a spacecraft, lauched from the Jiuquan Satellite Launch Center.
It is based on the JianBing 3 imagery reconnaissance satellite series platform.
A joint collaboration of the Ministry of Science and Technology of China, the Chinese Academy of Sciences, and Tsinghua University.
Data analysis is planned to be by a direct algebraic method - direct demodulation.
The satellite has three payloads, the high energy X-ray Telescope (20–250 keV), the medium energy X-ray telescope (5–30 keV), and the low energy X-ray telescope (1–15 keV)
The spacecraft had a launch mass of 2,800 kg (6,200 lb).

rovers.name: Yutu-2
rovers.description: Yutu-2 is a robotic lunar rover that formed part of the Chang'e 4 mission to the Moon. It was launched on 7 December 2018, 18:23 UTC

rovers.name: Chang'e 5-T1
rovers.description: Chang'e 5-T1 (嫦娥五号T1;) is an experimental robotic spacecraft that was launched to the Moon on 23 October 2014 by the CNSA.

rovers.name: Chang'e 5
rovers.description: Chang'e 5 (嫦娥五号) is the fifth lunar exploration mission of the Chinese Lunar Exploration Program, and China's first lunar sample-return mission.

rovers.name: Zhurong
rovers.description: Zhurong (祝融) is a Mars rover that is China's first rover to land on another planet. It is part of the Tianwen-1 mission to Mars conducted by the CNSA

spaceports.name: Taiyuan Satellite Launch Center
spaceports.description: The Taiyuan Satellite Launch Center (TSLC) also known as Base 25 (Chinese: 二十五基地), is a People's Republic of China space and defense launch facility.

spaceports.name: Jiuquan Satellite Launch Center
spaceports.description: Jiuquan Satellite Launch Center (JSLC;酒泉卫星发射中心) is a Chinese space vehicle launch facility (spaceport) located in the Gobi Desert, Inner Mongolia.

spaceports.name: Wenchang Spacecraft Launch Site
spaceports.description: The Wenchang Spacecraft Launch Site (文昌航天发射场) located in Wenchang, Hainan, is China's fourth and southernmost space vehicle launch facility (spaceport).

spaceports.name: Xichang Satellite Launch Center
spaceports.description: The Xichang Satellite Launch Center (XSLC), also known as the Xichang Space Center, is a spaceport of China. It is located in Zeyuan Town, Sichuan Province.
